Award.AwardTitle: Multiscale Computations of Stiff Oscillatory Ordinary Differential Equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Stiff oscillatory ordinary differential equations are common mathematical models in many important scientific fields, ranging from classical celestial mechanics to atomistic dynamics in modern physics and chemistry. These models are gaining ever more importance as the computer capability increases. Numerous simulations based on such systems are being performed in order to predict the nature, for example, of propagation of cracks and dislocations in metals and under what condition certain proteins change shape and take on specific functions that can be used in drug design. Many fundamental phenomena are generated through delicate interactions between rapid oscillations.

The challenge is to simulate these highly oscillatory interactions over physically relevant time without having the quality of the output being damaged by numerical errors. The research of this proposal aims at developing a new multi-scale computational approach such that the interesting phenomena resulting from interaction between oscillations can be computed accurately and efficiently over long time. The corresponding mathematical analysis of the algorithms will also be performed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We conclude that this project is successful both in scientific and in educational aspects. To date, nineteen research ariticles have been either published or in the process of being published in major research journals  and three books have been edited. These results have already been referenced and used by other scientists in the field. 

The PIs, the related post-doc researchers and graduate students have all been invited in several major workshops and conferences to present results that came out of this project. The PI's have also organized several international workshops focussing on importatn aspect of multiscale computation. Among these workshops are: an annual program at Newton Institute in Cambridge University, as Banff International Research Station, at Mathematisches Forschungsinstitut Oberwolfach, and at IMA. 

This project has involved four graduate students who are actively pursuing PhD degree, and two post-doctoral researchers. One of the involved post-doctoral researchers is now an senior lecturer (equivalent of an assistant professor in the US) in an Israeli university. 

New numerical analysis courses are created so that certain elementary multiscale approaches are incoporated. We believe that these new elements are essential in training the next generation applied mathematicians and computational scientists. Furthermore, a new course titled “Multiscale modeling and computation” is being offered. This course is designed for advanced graduate students in our applied math and other interdisciplinary programs. 

 

Major finding: 

In the long time computation of highly oscillatory problems, one needs to be aware of hidden slow variables. They are essential in describing a system's effective property. The hidden slow variables may be formally unbounded in time; however, due to very strong averaging in the system's fast oscillations, these formally unbounded slow variables do generate slowly changing trajectories. These slow variables are important characterization of the underlying effective system, and cannot be ignored or be simply averaged out. The origin of these slow variables of a highly oscillatory system often come from resonance or near resonance in the oscillations. We developed new averaging theory which explains mathematically the mechanism of such slow variables. We also developed efficient numerical averaging methods for the approximation of these new type of slow variables. When oscillations in a system come to be nearly resonant, new time scales may be generated. Depending on how close these frequencies are, the effective can either be negligible or significant so that one needs to deal with the events that take place in the newly emerged time scale.

 

Intellectual merits:

The conducted research help delineate mathematically what it means for a dynamical system that appear to be highly oscillatory to possess slow modes; i.e. information that changes in a much slower time scale than what the state variables exhibit. With this, efficient numerical algorithms can be devised and tested rigorously. The conducted research also established mathematical link to the expansion methods that are developed in a different community to the type of multiscale methods being considered. The results  facilitate further synergistic advancement in this field.


Broader Impacts:

The conducted research is at the very mathematical heart of many important applications that effect our everyday life.
